title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement mike.mahoney.218@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to rrrem
text: outlines propose change rrrem.

title: Contributing to rrrem
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to rrrem
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to rrrem
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("mikemahoney218/rrrem", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to rrrem
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to rrrem
text: Please note rrrem project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Michael Mahoney. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Mahoney M (2022). rrrem: R Port 'RiverREM' Python Package. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://mikemahoney218.github.io/rrrem/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rrrem: An R Port of the 'RiverREM' Python Package},   author = {Michael Mahoney},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://mikemahoney218.github.io/rrrem/}, }

what: An R Port of the RiverREM Python Package
title: An R Port of the RiverREM Python Package
text: rrrem R port RiverREM package, letting use packages R’s spatial programming ecosystem produce relative elevation models. Specifically, package implements river-retrieving REM-producing elements RiverREM; R strong graphing support raster graphics, visualizations re-implemented (easily re-created using either base R ggplot2). Please note package made extremely quickly effectively untested – may sharp edges yet sanded , may breaking changes horizon.

title: An R Port of the RiverREM Python Package
text: can install development version rrrem like :

title: An R Port of the RiverREM Python Package
text: rrrem creates relative elevation models (REMs) based upon user-supplied digital elevation models (DEMs) river locations optionally downloaded via OpenStreetMap. , order use rrrem, first need get DEM. can get high-resolution DEMs areas United States using sf terrainr packages, like : data downloaded, ’re ready move actually using rrrem. main workhorse package make_rem() function, takes DEM (optionally, line geometry reflecting “target” river visualize) converts REM. can call function like : , well, ’s less package . Kinda anti-climax, . Rather re-implement visualization helpers RiverREM package, rrrem returns data formats R spatial visualization ecosystems recognize, making easy users hyper-customize visualizations without needing learn new plotting function. instance, rem object just created can plotted quickly via terra::plot():  , little elbow grease, can combine functions terra make customizable visualizations:
code: dem <- sf::st_as_sf(   data.frame(     y = c(43.412402, 43.489347),      x = c(-123.591623, -123.479736)   ),   coords = c("x", "y"),   crs = 4326 ) |>    sf::st_transform(3857) |>    terrainr::get_tiles() |>    purrr::chuck("elevation") |>    terrainr::merge_rasters() library(rrrem)  rem <- make_rem(dem) terra::plot(rem) dem <- terra::rast(dem)  hillshade <- terra::shade(   terra::terrain(dem, "slope", unit = "radians"),   terra::terrain(dem, "aspect", unit = "radians") )  trimmed_rem <- rem trimmed_rem[trimmed_rem > 200] <- 200  par(   oma = c(0, 0, 0, 0),   mar = c(0, 0, 0, 0),   mgp = c(0, 0, 0) )   terra::plot(   hillshade,    col = grey(0:100/100),    legend = FALSE,    axes = FALSE,   oma = NA,   mar = NA,   xaxs="i",    yaxs="i" )   terra::plot(   trimmed_rem,   col = viridis::mako(50, direction = -1),    legend = FALSE,    axes = FALSE,   add = TRUE,   alpha = 0.75 )

title: An R Port of the RiverREM Python Package
text: Please note rrrem project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

what: Interpolate elevations from points along a centerline — calc_centerline_interpolation
title: Interpolate elevations from points along a centerline — calc_centerline_interpolation
text: Interpolate elevations points along centerline

title: Interpolate elevations from points along a centerline — calc_centerline_interpolation
code: calc_centerline_interpolation(   points_on_line,   dem,   algorithm = "invdist:power=1",   gdal_options = NULL,   quiet = TRUE )

title: Interpolate elevations from points along a centerline — calc_centerline_interpolation
text: points_on_line output points_along_line(): sfc object points along centerline, used data points interpolation. dem Either SpatRaster (created via terra::rast()) object terra::rast() can read create SpatRaster. algorithm string control interpolation algorithm. See gdal_grid documentation https://gdal.org/programs/gdal_grid.html available algorithms customization options. gdal_options Optionally, vector options pass gdal_grid via sf::gdal_utils(). See full list options online https://gdal.org/programs/gdal_grid.html. See Details. quiet Boolean: execution proceed "quietly", without messages (TRUE) progress updates posted centerline download interpolation (FALSE)?

title: Interpolate elevations from points along a centerline — calc_centerline_interpolation
text: SpatRaster object (created terra::rast()), representing outputs interpolation process.

title: Interpolate elevations from points along a centerline — calc_centerline_interpolation
text: bulk processing time function involves calling gdal_grid via sf::gdal_utils(). results function call written TIFF file read back R session. can choose pass options gdal_grid. However, passing -, -txe, -tye, -tr, -outsize, zfield cause error. Possible options speed processing include passing c("-co", "NUM_THREADS=ALL_CPUS") order write TIFF using multiple threads, c("--config" "GDAL_CACHEMAX", "30%") (another value) increase cache utilization default 5%.

title: Interpolate elevations from points along a centerline — calc_centerline_interpolation
code: if (FALSE) { # rlang::is_interactive() dem <- system.file("elevation.tiff", package = "rrrem") centerline <- get_river_centerline(dem) center_points <- points_along_line(centerline, n_points = n_points) interpolated_raster <- calc_centerline_interpolation(   center_points,   dem,   quiet = quiet ) }

title: Get the
text: Get "centerline" longest river along DEM

title: Get the
text: dem Either SpatRaster (created via terra::rast()) object terra::rast() can read create SpatRaster. quiet Boolean: execution proceed "quietly", without messages (TRUE) progress updates posted centerline download interpolation (FALSE)?

title: Get the
text: sfc object (created sf::st_sfc()), LINESTRING geometry, representing center river within DEM area.

title: Get the
code: if (FALSE) { # rlang::is_interactive() dem <- system.file("elevation.tiff", package = "rrrem") centerline <- get_river_centerline(dem) }

what: Make a Relative Elevation Model (REM) — make_rem
title: Make a Relative Elevation Model (REM) — make_rem
text: function creates relative elevation model, REM, based input digital elevation model (DEM) trajectory river. Simple inverse distance weighting used calculate "base" elevations pixels within DEM, subtracted produce output REM.

title: Make a Relative Elevation Model (REM) — make_rem
code: make_rem(   dem,   centerline = NULL,   n_points = 1000,   algorithm = "invdist:power=1",   quiet = TRUE )

title: Make a Relative Elevation Model (REM) — make_rem
text: dem Either SpatRaster (created via terra::rast()) object terra::rast() can read create SpatRaster. centerline Optionally, sfc object (created via sf::sfc()) representing center target river base relative elevation model . NULL, default, longest river bounding box name OpenStreetMap used instead. n_points number sample points along river base interpolation . points make interpolation take longer. algorithm string control interpolation algorithm. See gdal_grid documentation https://gdal.org/programs/gdal_grid.html available algorithms customization options. quiet Boolean: execution proceed "quietly", without messages (TRUE) progress updates posted centerline download interpolation (FALSE)?

title: Make a Relative Elevation Model (REM) — make_rem
text: SpatRaster object (created terra::rast()), representing difference elevations dem interpolated elevation

title: Make a Relative Elevation Model (REM) — make_rem

what: Create a set of number of evenly spaced points along a line geometry — points_along_line
title: Create a set of number of evenly spaced points along a line geometry — points_along_line
text: Create set number evenly spaced points along line geometry

title: Create a set of number of evenly spaced points along a line geometry — points_along_line
Create a set of number of evenly spaced points along a line geometry — points_along_line
text: line line create points along. Must sfc object (created sf::st_sfc()) LINESTRING geometry. n_points number points along line create.

title: Create a set of number of evenly spaced points along a line geometry — points_along_line
text: sfc object POINT geometry length n_points.

title: Create a set of number of evenly spaced points along a line geometry — points_along_line
code: if (FALSE) { # rlang::is_interactive() dem <- system.file("elevation.tiff", package = "rrrem") centerline <- get_river_centerline(dem) center_points <- points_along_line(centerline, n_points = n_points) }

what: rrrem: An R Port of the 'RiverREM' Python Package — rrrem-package
title: rrrem: An R Port of the 'RiverREM' Python Package — rrrem-package
text: Build visualize relative elevation models ('REM') representing elevation relative river centerline. package R port existing Python 'RiverREM' package https://github.com/klarrieu/RiverREM.
